How Ford economy won
for Tiny Lund at Daytona

The Daytona 500 is one of America's
toughest stock car events. It measures
the toughness, stability, over-all performance and economy characteristics
of the cars that take up its challenge—
in a way that compresses years of driving
punishment into 500 blazing miles. This
year mechanical failures claimed over 50
per cent of the cars that entered. That's
why Tiny Lund's victory in a Ford (with
four other Fords right behind him) is a
remarkable testimony to sheer engineering excellence.
Lund attributed his victory in part to
the "missing pit stop." He made one less
pit stop for fuel than his competition—
proving that Ford economy can pay off
in some fairly unlikely situations!
Economy and the winner of the Daytona 500 might sound like odd bedfellows
at first. Yet economy is basic in every car
we make... yes, even the Thunderbird
is an economy car in its own way. Here's
what we mean .
Economy is the measure of service and
satisfaction the customer receives in relation to the price he pays for it. It does
not mean, however, austerity ... you
have taught us this. Americans want—
and we try hard to give them—cars that
are comfortable to ride in, fun to drive,
and powerful enough to get out of their
own way. Not many Americans want to
settle for basic transportation. You see
this in our sales figures—more than half
of our 1963 sales are coming from the top
of each model line. We're selling convertibles, hardtops, the jazzy cars ...
the bucket-seat, high-performance, luxury editions are going like hot cakes.
Yet for all the fun that people are
demanding in their cars, they still are

very conscious of the element of thrift—
of avoiding unnecessary expense. This is
the kind of economy we build into every
car from the compact Falcon to the luxurious Thunderbird.
There's a special economy,for instance,
In Ford's freedom from service. Every
car and virtually every wagon can travel
36,000 miles before it needs a major
chassis lubrication. Other routine service
has been reduced, too—because these
Fords are simply built better—and of
better materials—than ever before.
In its own elegant way, even the
Thunderbird gives you economy. It will
travel 100,000 miles or 3 years before you
have to lubricate the chassis. Thunderbirds have a way of becoming classics—
as a look at their remarkably high resale
value will quickly tell you. This, too, is
economy.
Once, long ago—before the arrival of
the Income Tax—a wealthy lady was
asked to comment on the solid gold
plumbing of her latest villa at Newport.
"So thrifty, my dear," said the dowager
."it will never, ever rust."
Economy then,is many things to many
people.Whatever economy means to you,
you're pretty sure to find it in a Ford.

And Round Again
Now that the poorly handled elections have capped
the term of the out-going Student Council with an appropriate crescendo of ineptitude, it behooves us to address the last worn segment of our nearly used typewriter
ribbon to the equally worn problem of the nature and
Junction of representative government on a University
campus. The question is, as it has always been, to define
the place of a political body in a community which is
essentially apolitical and our mind is, quite frankly,
divided on the subject. We have suggested that there is
no place for representative government under the present
organization of the Hopkins community; we have suggested ways to carve out such a place. Either reaction
would be valid under the circumstances and either way
a more realistic organization would be achieved.
The point is that there are too many people doing
the same kind of thing. Autonomous organizations such
as the Booster Club, Cotillion Board, and D.S.R.C. operate within their own fairly well defined spheres of activity, and in general, operate effectively. Thus, when
the Student Council ventures to do something, it inevitably encroaches on someone else's political turf. The
result of this has been apparent this year as a completely inactive and ineffective Council was scarcely
missed in the community it is supposed to represent
because all of its functions were either non-vital or
accounted for by someone else.
The lesson of the last few years is that there is
presently no need for an autonomous Student Council
and a set of equally autonomous activities at Hopkins.
The solution would he either to subordinate the Council
to the activities by establishing a co-ordinating committee of organization heads or to subordinate the activities
to the Council by giving the Council their functions and
establishing them as committees of the parent group.
In either case efficiency, the summum bonurn of the
organizers among us, would be served without serious

The Daytona 500 is one of America's

Lund attributed his victory in part to

pit stop for fuel than his competition—
proving that Ford economy can pay off
in some fairly unlikely situations!
Economy and the winner of the Daytona 500 might sound like odd bedfellows
at first. Yet economy is basic in every car
we make... yes, even the Thunderbird

what we mean .

satisfaction the customer receives in relation to the price he pays for it. It does
not mean, however, austerity ... you
have taught us this. Americans want—
and we try hard to give them—cars that
are comfortable to ride in, fun to drive,

of our 1963 sales are coming from the top
of each model line. We're selling convertibles, hardtops, the jazzy cars ...
the bucket-seat, high-performance, luxury editions are going like hot cakes.
Yet for all the fun that people are
demanding in their cars, they still are

very conscious of the element of thrift—
of avoiding unnecessary expense. This is
the kind of economy we build into every
car from the compact Falcon to the luxurious Thunderbird.

In Ford's freedom from service. Every
car and virtually every wagon can travel
36,000 miles before it needs a major

economy.

asked to comment on the solid gold
plumbing of her latest villa at Newport.
"So thrifty, my dear," said the dowager
."it will never, ever rust."

people.Whatever economy means to you,

And Round Again
Now that the poorly handled elections have capped
the term of the out-going Student Council with an appropriate crescendo of ineptitude, it behooves us to address the last worn segment of our nearly used typewriter
ribbon to the equally worn problem of the nature and
Junction of representative government on a University
campus. The question is, as it has always been, to define
the place of a political body in a community which is
essentially apolitical and our mind is, quite frankly,
divided on the subject. We have suggested that there is
no place for representative government under the present
organization of the Hopkins community; we have suggested ways to carve out such a place. Either reaction
would be valid under the circumstances and either way
a more realistic organization would be achieved.
The point is that there are too many people doing
the same kind of thing. Autonomous organizations such
as the Booster Club, Cotillion Board, and D.S.R.C. operate within their own fairly well defined spheres of activity, and in general, operate effectively. Thus, when
the Student Council ventures to do something, it inevitably encroaches on someone else's political turf. The
result of this has been apparent this year as a completely inactive and ineffective Council was scarcely
missed in the community it is supposed to represent
because all of its functions were either non-vital or
accounted for by someone else.
The lesson of the last few years is that there is
presently no need for an autonomous Student Council
and a set of equally autonomous activities at Hopkins.
The solution would he either to subordinate the Council
to the activities by establishing a co-ordinating committee of organization heads or to subordinate the activities
to the Council by giving the Council their functions and
establishing them as committees of the parent group.
In either case efficiency, the summum bonurn of the
organizers among us, would be served without serious
damage to our present relaxed, irresponsible, apathetic
carefree way of life.
Steve Roth, newly elected Student Council president, has another solution to the problem of making
representative government meaningful. Realizing that
what the Council needs is an extended sphere of activity,
he proposes to expand into realms which are now the
domain of the Administration.
He does not, unfortunately, specify what these are.
And the Administration has shown that it has little
patience with undergraduate schemes that are not
worked out in meticulous detail. Consequently, while
we are entirely in sympathy with Roth's motivations,
we must, on practical grounds, remain just a wee bit
skeptical.
By setting himself this kind of a task, Roth runs
head on into the bog which has nonchalantly absorbed
the best efforts of past groups. The Council must set a
direction for itself, a concrete goal involving concrete
means to an extremely nebulous end. We wish them luck.

The Battle For Peace
The Active Pacifists, a phenomen as characteristic
of the season as the blooming magnolias, have come
forth to remind us that there may never be another
Spring for them to demonstrate in. Decked out for
Easter in their finest Social Involvement, the members
of CONCERN have made an admirable effort to turn us
toward peace with their Easter-Passover peace walk.
The involvement of the name of Johns Hopkins
in this effort, and the presence of a number of men
among the marchers, who command respect, make it
impossible to ignore the questions raised by the demonstration. There 18 no necessity here to discuss peace, the
Bomb, Cuba etc. Audacity does not extend that far. What
does hear consideration is the nature of the Peace movement itself, specifically the politically unrealistic nature
of its appeals.
To he sure, a public demonstration increases the
general awareness of the problem. The political effectiveness of such a rally remains, however, extremely dubious.
One suspects that cries of anguish have singularly little
effect on the politic ans who make things happen in this
threatened world. And unless someone in an effective
position of power is profoundly influenced, all of the
public outrage in the world will do no good.
To be sure public opinion counts for something,
but it would appear that the considerable intellectual
talent which strolled on Easter Sunday would be put to
much better use if it were directed towards influencing
the real powers in this country in the language to which
they are accustommed. Were these men to bend their
efforts towards the establishment of a Peace lobby (or
the support of one if it already exists) their message
would be far more likely to take effect where it would do
the most good.
It would seem that effective political action would
he more readily influenced by effective political infighting than by more spectacular but less immediate means.

Although my son is a college freshman, I am glad to say that
he is still not too old to climb up on my lap and have a heartto-heart talk when things are troubling him. My boy is enrolled
at Harvard where he is studying to be a fireman. Front the
time he was a little tiny baby he always said he wanted to be
a fireman. Of course, my wife and I believed that he would
eventually grow out of it, but no sir, the little chap never
wavered in his ambition for one minute!
So here he is at Harvard today taking courses in net holding,
mouth-to-mouth breathing, carbon tetrachloride, and Dalmatian dogs. It is a full schedule for the young man, and that, in
fact, is exactly what we talked about when last he climbed
upon my lap.

major requirements. He doesn't have so much as one hour a
week to sample any of the fascinating courses outside his major
—history, literature, language, science, or any of the thousand
and one things that appeal to his keen young mind.
I am sure that many of you find yourselves in the same
scholastic bind; you are taking so many requirements that you
can't find time for some appealing electives. Therefore, in today's column I will forego levity and give you a brief survey in
a subject that is probably not included in your curriculum.
